awd_titl_txt: NeuroDataRR. Collaborative Research: Testing the relationship between musical training and enhanced neural coding and perception in noise
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will determine whether formal musical training is associated with enhanced neural processing and perception of sounds, including speech in noisy backgrounds. Music forms an important part of the lives of millions of people around the world, and it is one of the few universals shared by all known human cultures. Yet its utility and potential evolutionary advantages remain a mystery. This project will test the hypothesis that early musical exposure has benefits that extend beyond music to critical aspects of human communication, such as speech perception in noise. In addition, the investigators will test whether early musical training is associated with less severe effects of aging on the ability to understand speech in noisy backgrounds. Degraded ability to understand speech in noise is a common complaint among older listeners and hearing loss has been shown to be associated with social isolation and more rapid cognitive and health declines. If formal musical training is shown to affect improved perception and speech communication in later life, the outcomes could have a potentially major impact on quality of life,

Earlier studies have suggested relationships between early musical training and improved auditory neural processing and perception, but the studies' impact has been limited by small sample numbers and inconsistent methods between different studies. This project will test a large number of participants (N=360) with uniform recruitment criteria and testing protocols across six different sites. Measures will include the neural frequency following response (FFR) to speech sounds, behavioral frequency selectivity, speech perception in noise, speech perception against a background of competing talkers, pitch discrimination, and auditory masking. The participants will also complete other assessments, including a personality inventory questionnaire, a profile of musical perception skills, a spatial reasoning test to assess general cognitive ability, as well as a background questionnaire to determine socio-economic status, education, and musical background. Participants will be selected to span a wide range of ages and musical experience. The neural data and the speech perception measures will be related to factors of musical training, such as the number of years of musical training and the age at which musical training began. Scientific rigor will be assured by preregistering the study and the analyses and by making the data and analysis code publicly available via a dedicated website.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF NeuroDataRR grant supported the first large-scale, multi-site replication study examining therelationship between musical training and sound neural coding and perception. One goal was todefinitively answer whether musicians outperform non-musicians on a variety of perceptual (e.g.,speech in background sounds, pitch perception, etc.) and neural (e.g., encoding for frequency)measures. Another goal was to better understand whether musical training might offset the effects ofaging on how we perceive sound and how the brain processes sound. An inability to understand speechin noisy surroundings is a very common complaint among older people, even those with clinically normalhearing. Such difficulties can contribute to social isolation, poor quality of life, and negative healthoutcomes. If musical training is definitively linked to better speech understanding in noise in olderpeople, the implications in terms of public and educational policy are profound. Data collection for the study is currently ongoing due to delays caused by the COVID-19 pandemic, butso far n=210 participants varying in age (18-83) and formal years of musical training (0-38 years) havecompleted the study, which has a final sample size goal of n ≥ 350. Formal statistical analyses arepreregistered on the Open Science Framework (https://osf.io/duq34/) and will be conducted once fulldata collection is complete, including examining the important relationship between musical training,aging, and speech perception. Preliminary trends suggest the musician advantage is most robust fortasks directly relevant to musical training (e.g., melody perception and pitch discrimination), but it is tooearly to make definitive claims. Degraded ability to understand speech in noise is a common complaint among older listeners, and onethat can have a profound impact on quality of life, as has been shown by the associations betweenhearing loss, social isolation, and more rapid cognitive and health declines. If this hypothesis issupported by our large, multi-site study, broader impacts could include efforts to increase access tomusic training at an early age with the aim of protecting against later effects of aging and to initiatelarger longitudinal studies to establish a causal link between musical training and the targetedoutcomes. On the other hand, if the hypothesis is not supported by our study, then the publicunderstanding of how music shapes brain function and perception will be revised. Given the highinherent public interest in music, and the intriguing nature of the proposed links between music,speech, and the brain, this work is likely to generate considerable public and press attention. The process of carrying out this project has also had a broader impact on science. The process ofimplementing a large-scale study of this kind has been documented on our study blog,www.soundbrainscience.com/blog, which is available to scientists and the public. The computersoftware for this project is available free for others to use at https://github.com/kellywhiteford/Musicianship.
